page.title: Adverbs and AdvP - Manner Adverbs
page.introduction:
Manner adverbs directly modify the verb and usually end in -ly in English. They do not seem to have clear counterparts of other phrase types, except possibly some comparatives, such as as fast as he could. (Comparatives will be dealt with in
Basic, Single-clause Sentences - Copular, Comparative and Existential and
Coordination Constructions.) In English, manner adverbs can be modified by very and so, as in:

form.prompt: Some languages do not have separate words, but rather use verbal affixes to express manner. Key examples of how your language expresses manner here, without any degree words. If the manner adverbs are affixes, key a hyphen to show which side they attach on.

radioGroup.radio: No, they are all written as part of the verb

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have degree words which can modify the manner adverbs?

form.instruction: In the lexicon, key the feature manner on all adverbs that express manner.

In the lexicon, key the features makeDeg modifies_manner on the degree words to change the category and allow it to modify manner adverbs. Simply add the modifies_manner feature if this same degree word can modify temporal and/or locative adverbs and you already marked it with those features.
